The correct chronological order of the sub-events is option A: 2 -> 6 -> 8 -> 4 -> 1 -> 3 -> 7 -> 5. 

The lecture starts with dramatic orchestral music playing over a Saturn view (option 2), followed by a discussion on red and blue shifts as radial velocities (option 1). Then, the speaker introduces brown dwarfs using Orion Nebula images (option 3). Afterward, he mentions the Sun's distance from Earth (option 4) and shows a binary revolution diagram (option 4). Another speaker then promotes the playlist and asks viewers to subscribe (option 5). The lecture continues with a discussion on the closest stars (option 6), followed by a description of the white dwarf Sirius B (option 7). Finally, the lecture ends with the speaker saying that it's been a cool L-dwarf visual binary that rotates over time (option 8), and the slide changes to show dated red dots (option 8).

The correct chronological order of the sub-events is option A: 4 -> 2 -> 5 -> 6 -> 1 -> 3.
Firstly, he discusses F-stars on the main sequence and calls protostars "babies" while the H-R diagram (FIGURE 18.14) is displayed, which indicates that event 4 occurred first.
Next, he explains that when the two stars can't be resolved, you collect all the light to make a light curve, with FIGURE 18.10 on screen, which suggests that event 2 happened next.
He emphasizes how enormous VY Canis Majoris is compared to the Sun on a comparison slide (FIGURE 18.16), which implies that event 3 took place after event 2.
He mentions 20 years of NASA research at Missouri State while talking about yellow big stars and white dwarfs as the mass-luminosity graph (FIGURE 18.9) appears, indicating that event 4 happened during this time frame.
